One who practices in this way should understand what is meant by emptiness of self-characteristics.

Being harmed is the characteristic of form, being able to experience is the characteristic of feeling, grasping is the characteristic of perception, creating is the characteristic of mental formations, being aware is the characteristic of consciousness. The self-characteristics of all conditioned and unconditioned dharmas are empty of their own characteristics, not an accumulation, not destructible, not graspable.
Why is it so?
The nature of all dharmas is such.
This is called emptiness of self-characteristics.
One who practices in this way should understand what is meant by emptiness of all dharmas.

All dharmas refers to form, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness; eye up to mind; form up to dharmas; eye and form as conditions giving rise to consciousness up to mind and dharmas as conditions giving rise to consciousness. These conditioned and unconditioned dharmas are called all dharmas. They are empty, not an accumulation, not something that can be destroyed or grasped.
Why is it so?
The nature of dharmas is like this.
This is called the emptiness of all dharmas.
One who practices in this way should know the truth: What is called the emptiness of non-apprehension?
All dharmas are non-apprehensible, not an accumulation, not something that can be destroyed or grasped.
Why is it so?
The nature of dharmas is like this.
This is called the emptiness of non-apprehension.
One who practices in this way should know the truth: What is called the emptiness of non-existence?
All non-existent things are non-apprehensible, not an accumulation, not something that can be destroyed or grasped.
Why is it so?
The nature of dharmas is like this.
This is called the emptiness of non-existence.
One who practices in this way should know what is meant by the emptiness of existing phenomena.
In the combination, there is no substance, it is not an accumulation, it cannot be destroyed, and it cannot be grasped.
Why is it so?
It is because the nature of all dharmas is like this.
This is called the emptiness of existing phenomena.
One who practices in this way should know what is meant by the emptiness of non-existing phenomena and existing phenomena.
Non-substance is the emptiness of non-substance, substance is the emptiness of substance, it is not an accumulation, it cannot be destroyed, and it cannot be grasped.
Why is it so?
It is because the nature of all dharmas is like this.
This is called the emptiness of non-existing phenomena and existing phenomena.
One who practices in this way should know what is meant by the emptiness of the inherent characteristics of phenomena.
Dharma refers to the five aggregates. The five aggregates are empty, they are not an accumulation, they cannot be destroyed, and they cannot be grasped.
Why is it so?
It is because the nature of all dharmas is like this.
This is called the emptiness of the inherent characteristics of phenomena.
One who practices in this way should know what is meant by the emptiness of the inherent characteristics of non-existing phenomena.
The non-existent dharmas are the unconditioned dharmas. This emptiness of the unconditioned dharmas is not an accumulation, cannot be destroyed, and cannot be grasped.
Why is it so?
It is because the nature of all dharmas is such.
This is called the emptiness of the non-existent nature of the non-existent.
One who practices in this way should understand what is meant by the emptiness of one's own nature of one's own dharmas.
The emptiness of one's own nature of one's own dharmas is not created by wisdom, not created by views, not an accumulation, cannot be destroyed, and cannot be grasped.
Why is it so?
It is because the nature of all dharmas is such.
This is called the emptiness of one's own nature of one's own dharmas.
One who practices in this way should understand what is meant by the emptiness of the nature of other dharmas of other dharmas.

Whether the Buddha appears in the world or not, the Dharma abides, the nature of the Dharma, the state of the Dharma, the realm of the Dharma, and the ultimate truth remain as they are, with the nature and characteristics always abiding without change. This emptiness of all dharmas is not an accumulation, cannot be destroyed, and cannot be grasped.
Why is it so?
It is because the nature of all dharmas is such.
This is called the emptiness of other dharmas and the characteristics of other dharmas.

Thus, practitioners should know this as it really is. Knowing this, they can enable sentient beings to be free from the notion of sentient beings, free from the notions of all conditioned forces, of form, of feeling, of perception, and of consciousness, free from the notion of the eye and so forth up to the notion of the mind, free from the notion of form and so forth up to the notion of mental objects, and then establish all sentient beings in the unconditioned realm of the three vehicles.
If there are practitioners who realize these dharmas as they really are, they are said to cultivate well.
Those sentient beings who have previously cultivated these dharmas will hear the sound of this supreme and profound Dharma.
There may be sentient beings who have not planted good roots, but they will also hear the sound of this Dharma.
